metadata./Keywords: Ganglioneuroma; Trigeminal nerve; Fifth cranial nerve; Brain stem
metadata./Title: An intracranial odyssey: pediatric ganglioneuroma arising from the trigeminal ganglion: a case report and review of the literature
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Ganglioneuroma represents an uncommon benign tumor arising from the sympathetic nerves, and its 
development from the fifth nerve is an infrequent entity. Few ganglioneuromas arising from the fifth nerve have been 
discussed in literature. The authors describe the second pediatric ganglioneuroma arising from the fifth nerve.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 7 year-old Asian male suffering from left-sided facial paresthesia, accompanied by several 
episodes of complex seizures over the past 2 years, presented to our clinic. The patient also complained of sudden unconsciousness and concurrent upward gaze lasting less than a minute. A brain computed tomography scan 
and magnetic resonance imaging revealed an isodense lesion containing focal calcifications measuring 31 × 28 mm 
and a solid mass extending from the pontine surface to Meckel’s cave, probably originating from the fifth nerve or its 
root entry zone. The lesion was mildly hypointense on T1-weighted sequences and hyperintense on T2-weighted 
and fluid attenuated inversion recovery sequences. Gadolinium injection revealed only minimal heterogeneous 
enhancement. Histopathologic and immunohistochemical findings were consistent with ganglioneuroma. A lateral 
approach via retrosigmoid incision and suboccipital lateral craniectomy toward the cerebellopontine angle was per formed under neuromonitoring supervision, and the postoperative period was uneventful.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Although ganglioneuroma arising from the fifth nerve is an extremely rare entity, it should be considered when diagnosing lesions in Meckel’s cave or the cerebellopontine angle cistern.
Keywords  Ganglioneuroma, Trigeminal nerve, Fifth cranial nerve, Brain stem
sections.Introduction:
Introduction
Ganglioneuromas represent the most noninvasive, 
mature form of neuroblastic tumors. Such tumors are 
usually associated with autonomic ganglia and manifest 
before the second decade of life [1]. They typically derive 
from neural crest cells and may originate from existing 
sympathetic tissue [2], including the posterior mediasti num, neck, adrenal gland, pelvis, and retroperitoneum. 
The most frequent locations for such entities are the ret roperitoneum and posterior mediastinum. However, they 
may infrequently be found in the intracranial region, with 
sporadic reports originating from the trigeminal nerve Open Access

[1, 2]. A clinical diagnosis that distinguishes such tumors 
from mimicking ones remains challenging owing to their 
rarity [3, 4]. Few reports of trigeminal ganglioneuroma 
are currently available in literature, most of which come 
from East Asia [1]. The authors describe the second case 
of a left-sided trigeminal ganglioneuroma extending to 
the cerebellopontine angle (CPA) in a pediatric patient.
Case presentation
The present patient is a 7 year-old Asian male complain ing of paresthesia on the left side of his face. He has 
experienced episodes of complex seizures over the past 
2 years, presenting as sudden unconsciousness and con current upward gaze lasting for less than a minute. He 
had been treated with topiramate and sodium valproate, 
which resulted in an appropriate treatment response. The patient reported no significant medical, family, or psy chosocial history. Neurological examinations were also 
unremarkable. Owing to the new-onset paresthesia, the 
patient underwent a brain computed tomography (CT) 
scan, revealing an isodense lesion containing focal cal cifications measuring 31 × 28 mm (Fig.  1). This study has 
been conducted in line with the SCARE 2020 guidelines 
to ensure quality reporting [5].
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed, 
and the lesion appeared as a solid mass extending from 
the pontine surface to Meckel’s cave, probably originat ing from the trigeminal nerve or its root entry zone. It 
was mildly hypointense in the T1 sequence and hyper intense in the T2 and fluid attenuated inversion recov ery (FLAIR) sequences. Gadolinium injection revealed 
only minimal heterogeneous enhancement Fig.  1. Despite 
Fig. 1 The brain computed tomography scan revealed a focal calcified isodense lesion (arrow A) in the left cerebellopontine angle. T1-weighted 
brain magnetic resonance imaging shows hypointensity (arrow B), and T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging shows hyperintensity (arrow 
C) in the left cerebellopontine angle with an extension to the left side of Meckel’s cave. Gadolinium injection reveals minimal heterogeneous 
enhancement (arrow D)
Page 3 of 8
 Ebrahimzadeh et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:600 
 
the compressive effect on the brainstem, there was no 
evidence of hydrocephalus. Owing to the evidence of 
brainstem and fourth ventricle compression, surgical 
intervention was performed.
Under neuromonitoring supervision, we approached 
the patient in the lateral position via a retrosigmoid inci sion and suboccipital lateral craniectomy toward the 
CPA. Initially, the tumor appeared as a well-circum scribed encapsulated mass with an elastic consistency. It 
had compressed the trigeminal nerve medially. Despite a 
downward compression effect, no adhesion or invasion 
was seen in the VII–VIII cranial nerve complex. We ini tiated sharp debulking of the lesion. The intraoperative 
frozen section specimen was reported to favor schwan noma. The lesion appeared to originate from the trigemi nal nerve (Fig.  1). After defining the plane between the 
brainstem and the tumor, the lesion was carefully dis sected from the trigeminal nerve exit zone to Meckel’s 
cave, and gross total resection was performed.
The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for a 
day and then to the ward for 4 days. No new neurological 
deficits were observed. He was discharged on postopera tive day 5. Additionally, his facial paresthesia completely 
resolved during a 3 month follow-up.
Histopathologic examination revealed haphazardly 
arranged nerve bundles of bland-looking Schwann cells 
in a hypocellular background. Clusters of mature gan glion cells with mild pleomorphism, prominent nucle oli, and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm containing 
Nissl bodies were noted. Immunohistochemical analysis 
showed positive staining for S100, synaptophysin, and 
SOX10. IDH1, Olig2, EMA, CD34, and glial fibrillary 
acidic protein (GFAP) were negative in tumor cells, and 
Ki67 was about 1%. Overall, these findings were consist ent with ganglioneuroma Fig. 2.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Ganglioneuroma, neuroblastoma, and ganglioneuroblas toma are categorized as neuroblastic lesions originating 
from the peripheral nervous system’s neural crest cells. 
Unlike ganglioneuroblastoma or neuroblastoma, which 
have more invasive behavior and typically affect younger 
people, ganglioneuroma represents a well-defined, 
benign, slow-growing lesion that clinically remains 
asymptomatic until it reaches a large enough size to com press nearby structures intracranially, resulting in symp toms owing to compression of adjacent structures. It is 
routinely found to occur in older pediatric patients and 
young adults, with approximately 80% of cases seen in 
patients not older than 30 years and no meaningful sex 
predisposition [3, 6–8]. Table  1 provides the previously reported cases of intracranial ganglioneuroma of the 
trigeminal nerve.
The posterior mediastinum and retroperitoneum are 
two well-known regions for ganglioneuroma. However, it 
has been rarely reported in the cranial nerve ganglia, cer ebellum, orbit, sella turcica, cranial vault, parapharyngeal 
tissue, spinal cord, mandible, tongue, gastrointestinal 
tract, bladder, uterus, visceral ganglia, ovary, testes, sper matic cord, prostate, bone, and skin [2–4, 7–18]. Similar 
intracranial regions, such as the internal auditory canal 
and middle ear, have also been infrequently described 
[14, 19–21]. The intracranial presentation of such lesions, 
however, remains extremely rare.
The underlying etiology of ganglioneuroma is not yet 
well understood. Several hypotheses have been proposed 
to explain the origin of such tumors. They might arise 
from a hamartomatous malformation involving ectopic 
sympathetic nervous tissue; the tumor may originate 
from neuroblastoma differentiation or may exist as multi potential precursor cells throughout the period of embry ological development. From a familial predisposition 
perspective, no definitive evidence is available; however, 
some reports suggest an association with multiple endo crine neoplasia syndrome type 2B and neurofibromatosis 
type 1. Females with Turner syndrome are highly prone 
to developing neural crest-derived tumors and may have 
a higher likelihood of developing ganglioneuromas [3, 22, 
23]. Hayes and collaborators shed more light on this, sug gesting that ganglioneuroma may develop spontaneously 
or present secondary to chemotherapy or radiation ther apy for neuroblastomas [24].
Imaging
Although the definitive diagnosis of ganglioneuroma pri marily relies on histopathologic evaluations, MRI and CT 
scans provide information regarding the size, location, 
components of the lesion, and its relationship to nearby 
structures, which is critical in determining a surgical 
plan. CT scans often reveal a well-differentiated, lowdensity mass with punctate calcification in about 20%–
42% of cases [8]. Ichikawa and collaborators [25] pointed 
out that the morphology of the calcifications could pro vide a remarkable characteristic factor to distinguish 
benign tumors from malignancies. While extensive 
patchy or irregular calcification indicates malignancy, 
grain-like or scattered punctate calcification implies 
benign lesions [8, 25]. MRI is superior to CT in dem onstrating blood vessels surrounding and compressing 
the lesion. However, conventional MRI alone might fail 
to differentiate trigeminal ganglioneuroma from other 
extra-axial or tumor-like masses since it does not provide 
detailed insights regarding the actual tumor extent, cel lularity, tumor type, and grading. By contrast, advanced 
Page 4 of 8 Ebrahimzadeh et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:600 
MRI sheds more light on the histological characteristics 
and tumor physiological and metabolic features, includ ing angiogenesis classification, cellularity, and mitotic 
indices [4].
Histopathology and immunohistochemically
Ganglioneuroma comprises single or clustered mature 
Schwannian stroma and giant ganglion cells. It typically 
lacks components of intermediate cells, neuroblasts, or 
mitotic figures, which would imply malignant differen tiation [8 ]. Ganglioneuroma is classified into maturing 
and mature subtypes on the basis of the international 
neuroblastoma pathology classification of neuroblas tic tumors [8 ]. A typical ganglioneuroma consists of 
Schwannian stroma and mature ganglion cells. In contrast, tumors with fully matured ganglion cells are 
uncommon (nearly 7%) [26]. It is characterized by reac tivity for vimentin, S-100, synaptophysin, and other 
neuronal markers. Additionally, Ki-67 serves as an 
immunomarker for cellular proliferation [27].
Management
Considering that such tumors exhibit well-circum scribed benign patterns, gross total resection is 
regarded as curative, and radiation and chemotherapy 
are not helpful in treatment. Subtotal resection is con sidered sufficient in cases where the tumor is in close 
proximity to vital structures. Routine postoperative fol low-up is highly recommended, as slow progression of 
the partially resected lesion is possible, and malignant 
Fig. 2 Histopathologic view of tumoral specimens. A Haphazard nerve bundles along with ganglion cells, hematoxylin and eosin stain, × 100. 
B Clusters of mature ganglion cells, hematoxylin and eosin stain, × 400. C Synaptophysin is positive mainly in ganglion cells, indicated by arrow, 
immunohistochemical stain, × 400. D CD34 highlighting vessels is shown with arrows, negative in the tumoral cells, immunohistochemical 
stain, × 100. E Glial fibrillary acidic protein is negative, immunohistochemical stain, × 100

transformation of ganglioneuroma has been rarely 
reported [ 28–30].
Conclusion
Despite the rarity of pediatric ganglioneuromas aris ing from the trigeminal nerve, their clinical presentation 
can mimic other, more common pathologies, warrant ing thorough imaging and histopathological evaluation. 
Advanced MRI is valuable for the preoperative differenti ation of trigeminal ganglioneuroma from similar tumors 
and tumor-like masses. When imaging does not yield a 
definitive diagnosis, trigeminal ganglioneuroma should 
be considered as a possible explanation.
Abbreviations
CT scan  Computed tomography scan
MRI  Magnetic resonance imaging
CPA  Cerebellopontine angle
Acknowledgements
Not applicable.
Author contributions
All co-authors read and approved the final manuscript.
Funding
Not applicable.
Availability of data and materials
Data sharing does not apply to this article as no datasets were generated or 
analyzed during the current study.
Declarations
Ethics approval and consent to participate
According to our institution’s ethics committee, ethical approval for the cur rent study is not required since our patient’s management was on the basis of 
approved options and was not found to be controversial.
Consent for publication
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient’s next-of-kin for 
publication of this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the 
written consent is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal.
Competing interests
The authors have no conflicts of interest to disclose. All co-authors have 
checked and agree with the final manuscript’s contents, and there is no 
financial interest to declare.
